facts.text: This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution filed by a firm of building contractors challenging the validity of provisions of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948 imposing tax on supply of materials in construction works treating it as a sale.

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution, and the question that is raised therein for our decision is as to the validity of certain provisions of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948  East Pb. XLVI of 1948 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, imposing a tax oil the supply of materials in companystruction works treating it as a sale.

facts.text: Petitioners entered into a contract with the Military Engineering Services Department of the Government in December 1956 for the construction of certain buildings known as Married accommodation at Ambala Cantonment.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are a firm of building companytractors. In December, 1956, they entered into a companytract with the Military Engineering Services Department of the Government for the companystruction of certain buildings known as Married accommodation at Ambala Cantonment

facts.text: Petitioners received a sum of Rs. 32,000 on January 31, 1957, as advance from the Government.

(2) for periods commencing from April 1, 1955 onwards, calling to produce account books and attend hearing on February 16, 1957.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 7, 1958 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.

facts.text: East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948 (East Pb. XLVI of 1948) imposes tax on supply of materials in construction works treating it as a sale.

anchor.surface_text: the validity of certain provisions of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948  East Pb. XLVI of 1948 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, imposing a tax oil the supply of materials in companystruction works treating it as a sale.

facts.text: Tenders called for and received for executing works for a lump sum; petitioners' tender dated December 15, 1956 accepted by Deputy Chief Engineer on behalf of President of India for lump sum of Rs. 9,74,961.

anchor.surface_text: The tenders which where called for and received were for executing works for a lump sum, and in his acceptance of the tender of the petitioners dated December 15, 1956, the Deputy Chief Engineer stated The above tender was accepted by me on behalf of the President of India for a lump sum of Rs. 9,74,961.

facts.text: Petitioners to construct nine blocks, amounts worked out treating each block as one unit.

anchor.surface_text: How this amount is made up is given in Annexure E to the reply statement. It will be seen therefrom that the petitioners were to companystruct nine blocks, and the amounts are worked out treating each of the blocks as one unit, and the figures are totalled up.

facts.text: Respondents contend that the building contract entered into by petitioners with Government comprised a distinct agreement for sale of materials.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we have number to companysider the companytention advanced by Mr. Bindra for the respondents that the building companytract entered into by the petitioners with the Government was number an agreement simpliciter for the companystruction of works, but that on its true companystruction, it companyprised a distinct agreement for the sale of materials.

facts.text: Court holds there was no agreement for sale of materials as such by petitioners to Government; contract is one and indivisible lump sum contract for construction.

anchor.surface_text: It is impossible on this evidence to hold that there was any agreement for sale of the materials as such by the petitioners to the Government.

facts.text: Rule 33 of General Conditions of Contracts: All stores and materials brought to the Site shall become and remain the property of Government until removal after completion when they revert to Contractor.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 33 which was particularly relied on provides All stores and materials brought to the Site shall become and remain the property of Government and shall number be removed off the Site without the prior written approval of the G. E. But whenever the works are finally companypleted, the companytractor shall at his own expense forthwith remove from the Site all surplus stores and materials originally supplied by him and upon such removal, the same shall retest in and become the property of the Contractor.

facts.text: Court holds Rule 33 does not effect a sale of materials to Government.

anchor.surface_text: That this is number the true meaning of the rule will be clear when regard is had to other provisions in the rules.

facts.text: Following State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd., there is no sale of materials in building contract and no tax can be levied thereon under Entry 48 List II of Govt of India Act 1935.

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution, and the question that is raised therein for our decision is as to the validity of certain provisions of the East Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948

issues.text: the main ground of attack being that the legislature of the Province of Punjab had under Entry 48 in List II of Sch. VII to the Government of India Act, 1935, no power to impose tax on the supply of materials in construction works as there was no sale in fact or in law of those materials, and that the provisions of the Act which sought to do it were ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the petitioners filed the present petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the legality of the assessment proceedings, the main ground of attack being that the legislature

issues.text: whether the building contract entered into by the petitioners with the Government was not an agreement simpliciter for the construction of works, but that on its true construction, it comprised a distinct agreement for the sale of materials. The question is whether the contract of the petitioners with the Government for construction was one and indivisible, or whether it was a combination of an agreement for sale of materials and an agreement for work and labour

anchor.surface_text: The tenders which where called for and received were for executing works for a lump sum, and in his acceptance of the tender of the petitioners dated December 15, 1956, the Deputy Chief Engineer stated The above tender was accepted by me on behalf of the President of India for a lump sum of Rs. 9,74,961.

(ii) which is what is applicable to the present case, there is no reference to sale of goods, and that, accordingly, even if Entry 48 in List II is to be interpreted in a wide sense, the provision as actually enacted does not, in fact, tax the supply of materials in works contracts, treating it as a sale

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioners raised two other contentions, but they are unsubstantial and may be shortly disposed of. One was that in the definition of turnover in s. 2 j , el. ii which is what is applicable to the present case, there is no reference to sale of goods

issues.text: the definition of dealer in s. 2(d) required that the person should be engaged in the business of selling or supplying goods, that the petitioners who were building contractors were not engaged in the business of selling or supplying goods but of constructing buildings, and that therefore they were not dealers within that definition, and that as under s. 4 the tax could be imposed only on a dealer, the petitioners were not liable to be taxed

anchor.surface_text: But if the supply of materials in construction works can be regarded as a sale, then clearly building contractors are engaged in the sale of materials, and they would be within the definition of dealers under the Act.

arguments.claim: The legislature of the Province of Punjab had under Entry 48 in List II of Sch. VII to the Government of India Act, 1935, no power to impose tax on the supply of materials in construction works as there was no sale in fact or in law of those materials, and the provisions of the Act which sought to do it were ultra vires.

arguments.court_reasoning: Bound by State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley holding no sale in building contracts under Entry 48 per Sale of Goods Act definition.

arguments.claim: The expression 'sale of goods' in Entry 48 has the same import as in the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930; in a building contract there is no sale of materials as such, and Provincial Legislature had no power to impose tax thereon under Entry 48.

anchor.surface_text: This question is concluded by the decision of this Court in The State of Madras V. Gannon Dunkerley Co. Madras Ltd. wherein it has been held that the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 has the same import which it bears in the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930,

arguments.claim: The building contract entered into by the petitioners with the Government was not an agreement simpliciter for the construction of works, but on its true construction, it comprised a distinct agreement for the sale of materials.

arguments.claim: Rule 33 of General Conditions of Contracts vests materials brought to site in Government, effecting a sale of materials to Government.

anchor.surface_text: For the respondents reliance was placed on the rules appearing in the printed General Conditions of Contracts issued by the Government. arguments.court_reasoning: Rule ensures quality control, not purchase; surplus reverts without resale; analogous to Tripp v. Armitage and Reid v. Macbeth where approval/marking does not pass property as sale.

arguments.claim: Rule 33 and similar terms are inserted to ensure materials of right quality are used, not with intention of purchasing them; vesting temporary, surplus reverts to contractor.

holdings.text: the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 has the same import which it bears in the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930, that in a building contract there is no sale of materials as such, and that accordingly the Provincial Legislature had no power to impose a tax thereon under Entry 48

anchor.surface_text: This question is concluded by the decision of this Court in The State of Madras V. Gannon Dunkerley Co.  Madras  Ltd.  1  wherein it has been held that the expression sale of goods in Entry 48 has the same import which it bears in the Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly following binding precedent from State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd. interpreting 'sale of goods' under Entry 48 per Sale of Goods Act; no sale in building contracts

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we have no to consider the contention advanced by Mr. Bindra for the respondents that the building contract entered into by the petitioners with the Government was not an agreement simpliciter for the construction of works, but that on its true construction, it comprised a distinct agreement for the sale of materials.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract documents show lump sum tenders for executing works, acceptance for fixed sum Rs. 9,74,961 for nine blocks; indivisible nature evidenced by tender and acceptance terms

holdings.text: Rule 33 has no the effect of converting what is a lump sum contract for construction of buildings into a contract for the sale of materials used therein

anchor.surface_text: That this is not the true meaning of the rule will be clear when regard is had to other provisions in the rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule ensures materials quality and prevents removal; surplus reverts to contractor without resale; analogous to Tripp v. Armitage and Reid v. Macbeth where approval/marking does not pass property via sale

holdings.text: there has been no sale of the materials used by the petitioners in their constructions, and that no tax could be levied thereon

anchor.surface_text: It must therefore be held following the decision in The State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co.  Madras  Ltd.  2  that there has been no sale of the materials used by the petitioners in their constructions, and that no tax could be levied thereon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirming Gannon Dunkerley applied to facts: no separate sale, Rule 33 no sale; thus no taxable sale under Act

holdings.text: the charging section is s. 4(1), which makes it clear that the tax is on the gross turnover in respect of sales effected after the coming into force of the Act, and the obvious intention is to include the supply of materials in works contracts within the category of taxable turnover

anchor.surface_text: But the charging section is s. 4 1 , which makes it clear that the tax is on the gross turnover in respect of sales effected after the coming into force of the Act, and the obvious intention is to include the supply of materials in works contracts within the category of taxable turnover.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4(1) imposes tax on sales' gross turnover; s.2(j)(ii) defines turnover to include contracts, read with charging section intends to tax works supply as sale

holdings.text: if the supply of materials in construction works can be regarded as a sale, then clearly building contractors are engaged in the sale of materials, and they would be within the definition of dealers under the Act

anchor.surface_text: But if the supply of materials in construction works can be regarded as a sale, then clearly building contractors are engaged in the sale of materials, and they would be within the definition of dealers under the Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: approbation of the surveyor is not sufficient to constitute an acceptance passing property in materials; property passes only when materials are fixed to the building
precedents.cited_holding: It is said that the approbation of the surveyor is sufficient to constitute an acceptance by the defendants but that approbation is number given eo animo at all it is only to ascertain that they are such materials as are suitable for the purpose and notwithstanding that approval, it is only when they have been put up, and fixed to the house, in performance of the larger contract, that they are to be paid for.

anchor.surface_text: the premises of the hotel and had been  1   1839  4 M. W. 687 150 E. R. 1597, 16O3. approved by the clerk and returned to the insolvent for the purpose of being affixed. precedents.cited_proposition: approval does not pass title to materials before fixation

anchor.surface_text: In Reid v. Macbeth Gray 1 , the facts were similar. The dispute related to certain plates which had been prepared by contractors to be fitted in a ship. These plates had been passed by the surveyor and were marked with the number of the vessel and with marks showing the position which each plate was to occupy in the vessel.

precedents.cited_proposition: approval by surveyor and markings do not establish a contract of sale of materials apart from the construction contract or pass title thereto
precedents.cited_holding: the facts relied on did number establish a contract of sale of the materials apart from the contract to construct the ship, and that the title to the materials did number as such pass to the shipowners

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we have no to consider the contention advanced by Mr. Bindra for the respondents that the building contract entered into by the petitioners with the Government was not an agreement simpliciter for the construction of works, but that on its true construction, it comprised a distinct agreement for the sale of materials.
